title: 112_hr4118
content: The "Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012" aims to increase small business participation in multiple award contracts. The Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012 seeks to enhance small business involvement in multiple award contracts by mandating their inclusion to the maximum extent feasible. The Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012 aims to increase small business participation in set-aside programs and multiple award contracts through outreach initiatives. The Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012 aims to increase small business awareness and participation in multiple award contracts by providing education, assistance in becoming listed on contracts, and tracking participation. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. Section 3 of the Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 632) is amended to include various types of contracts such as those under the Federal Supply Schedule program, multi-agency contracts, and Government-wide acquisition contracts for information technology. The Small Business Act is amended to include contracts for information technology established for Government-wide use. The terms "blanket purchase agreement" and "basic ordering agreement" are defined in the Act. SEC. 4. ENSURING SMALL BUSINESS PARTICIPATION IN CONTRACTS. Section 15(g)(1) of the Small Business Act is amended to require the President to annually establish Government-wide goals for task orders and delivery orders placed against contracts awarded to small business concerns. The Small Business Act is amended to establish Government-wide goals for task orders and delivery orders placed against contracts awarded to small businesses, including those owned and controlled by women. SEC. 5. IMPROVEMENTS TO THE SMALL BUSINESS RESERVE. Section 15(j) of the Small Business Act is amended to increase the threshold from $100,000 to $200,000 and to include regulations for task or delivery orders placed against multiple award contracts, including those under the Federal Supply Schedule program. The Administrator will issue regulations within 120 days of the enactment of this Act. The General Services Administration will ensure correct size standards, non-manufacturer rule, and subcontracting provisions are implemented at the task order level. Additionally, they will ensure electronic ordering systems display accurate size information for small businesses seeking task order set-asides. SEC. 6. SMALL BUSINESS REPRESENTATION ON THE FEDERAL ACQUISITION REGULATORY COUNCIL. Amends Section 1302(b)(1) of title 41, United States Code to include the Administrator of the Small Business Administration. In case of a tie vote, the Administrator of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy will have the deciding vote.
